Running the following test

    class MongoUserDetailsManagerTest {
      @Rule val mongo = new MongoResource("test_insight")
      ...
    }

Results in

    java.lang.Exception: Field mongo must be public
	at
org.junit.runners.BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.validateRuleField(BlockJUnit4ClassRunner.java:184)

This is because the bytecode for scala public vars (public is the default
scope scala) are not public. 

To be able to use @Rule in scala I had to hack BlockJUnit4ClassRunner with:

    private void validateRuleField(Field field, List<Throwable> errors) {
        if (!MethodRule.class.isAssignableFrom(field.getType()))
	    errors.add(new Exception("Field " + field.getName()
                      + " must implement MethodRule"));
        //TP_HACK To allow for scala val's
        field.setAccessible(true);
        // if (!Modifier.isPublic(field.getModifiers()))
        // errors.add(new Exception("Field " + field.getName()
        //           + " must be public"));
	}

Might it be considered to allow for non-public fields as some kind of JUnit
option?

-barry
